title: What will be the 12-month percentage change in the Core Consumer Price Index for January 2018?
preds: December was 1.8%. That will place January between 1.6 and 2.0 (it doesn't change more than 0.2 in one month). These buckets are odd. Bucket B encompasses 1.6, 1.7, 1.8. Bucket C is just 1.9. Bucket D is 2.0, 2.1, 2.2. I'm thinking Bucket C is a mistake.
I think it would have popped up in the news if estimated to go above 2% but still...
Full employment is putting pressure on wages and therefore prices.

https://www.bls.gov/news.release/pdf/cpi.pdf i am tempted to go above 1.8% 
but these are gross numbers from 12. of Jan I am anciously looking for the latest numbers released today on the 29. Jan. for December 2017. how about you?

Had a more detailed look at the MoM changes, then looked at what that might translate into in terms of the YoY % change for January. Realised that there is some chance of it being less than 1.6% which I hadn't thought of before.

thanks @Xu,  for the valuable updates. since the December numbers will be pulished  on 29. January , and the 2018 numbers are forecasted very similar to 2017,  It remains upon my judgement on the brink of +/- 1.8 %. therfore i revise my estimates from 90/10% to 60/40, for the <1.8% / >1.8% it is now very much possible it goes >1.8% read yourself.
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-01-12/u-s-core-inflation-accelerates-amid-increase-in-shelter-costs
See @Xu's data on increasing shelter costs http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/678249
inflation creeping up if one includes food and fuel > more like 3% but this is not seaonally adjusted
Really challenged by this one - seems it will land right around 1.8%. Looked at OECD etc. and appears muted.
Jan 17 rolling off (was 2.3%) and Dec 17 was 1.8%.  Hard to believe a 1 month increase beyond 0.5%

Continue to believe will be right around 1.8% - but can’t tell if it might resolve slightly lower or higher. I do some upward pressure globally on rates (wind down of QE, India doing ok, Turkey doing well - from low base a year ago, China managed well, Europe continues better than expected, etc.but tight USA labour market may be starting to impact... given use of single decimal, believe it will be 1.8 or 1.9% - slight preference for 1.8 (12 months through Dec was 1.7%)
the world economy has change the way companies do buisness and one has

Since 2009, used since stable inflation period, the average move from month to month, in absolute value is 0.085% in Core CPI, so big jumps usually don't happen. The Standard deviation of absolute moves would be 1 Standard deviation move at 1.83%-1.70% and 2 SD move of 1.89% - 1.63%.

Fiscal stimulus and a tight labor market will put pressure on wages.  Consumer sentiment is strong and it seems all of the leading indicators for inflation are present.  Fed policy is still very tame from a historical perspective

See @Win10d's data and analysis, magnificent! http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/672776 See also @Khalid's observation that the base rate has been between 1.7 and 1.8 over the last eight months http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/673245

New CPI (December) numbers released today. https://www.bls.gov/charts/consumer-price-index/consumer-price-index-by-category.htm AGHHHH is what that does for me. It's sitting at 1.8%. Looking at the individual breakdowns... IDK. If I'm honest there is no real strong correlations that I can see.  1. Even if Jan has a big jump in monthly CPI, the 12month is more muted. Therefore the possibilities are really between 1.6-1.8 and 1.8-2. If we're getting technical, 1.6-1.8 category is slightly larger (includes 1.6 and 1.8) where the other doesn't include the bookends.... so pure probability, given all chance, is stronger on that side slightly. 2. FREDs longterm CPI seems pretty linear: https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/PCEPILFE which lends to the change staying about 1.8 +/- 0.1. 3. A look at Dec to Jan 12 month changes in CPI from 2008 to today shows:
-3 decreases
-2 no change
-4 increases
if anything that bodes for a likelyhood of a change happening, not really any direction. I looked at this mostly to gauge if time of year had any affect on CPI. 4. CIP all items seems to be a more volatile version (makes sense since it adds in energy and food) and at times seems to be both leading and lagging or somewhere inbetween (or not even correlated). I'll toss that up to WTF. 5. Doing the pure math, January 2018 monthly raw CPI would need to be 0.43% to push the Jan 12 month over the 1.8 threshold. Although GJO seems to be using only out to 1 decimal which means if Labor would need to report 1.9, the actual amount would need to be 1.85% for the Jan 12 month, which means raw Jan 2018 cpi needs to be 0.47%.  This means December to January increase of the raw CPI change needs to be 0.44%. The average of the 9 years of the D-J raw CPI change is 0.35%. Last time over 0.44% was in the recession (0.56% in 2009). Last 3 years avg was 0.41% increase D-J raw. ***I pulled the data for #5's analysis-https://data.bls.gov/  using this table: Series Title:  All items less food and energy in U.S. city average, all urban consumers, not seasonally adjusted I'm going to say that the likelyhood is much greater it stays within 1.6-1.8 for these reasons. I don't think consumer sentiment or the supply side pricing to meet it is getting that much better. If anything maybe a plateau. I think GJO will use the 1 decimal news release to measure which further drives to the 1.8% inclusive. The argument for overweight >1.8 is that the tax change will drive up consumer buying but that might not drive up prices in the short term. It possibly drives down prices if suppliers are looking to move merchandise and take advantage of extra cash in the hands of consumers. I'm going to break from the average and strongly overweight the lower bracket.
Just checked the last 12 months, WAY more certain now.
Not my best spread, but yeah.  I don't expect a spike in inflation for the month.

Considering food and energy are excluded (they vary more than others) surprised by people selecting 2% increase. Unless I’ve understood the bureau of labour stats incorrectly it looks closer to 1.8% - especially after you remove Nov and Dec 2016 from 12 month average. Possible I’ve missed something the others haven’t,however.

Considering the current rate is 1.7%, the answer choices show an upward bias by the question writer. That said, the coming jobs losses due to the Trump tax "cut" (employees are now suddenly 14% more expensive due to reductions in taxes and their accompanying write-offs) shouldn't start affecting inflation until the summer.
I predict a small pick up because of stock market
Responding to data presented by @Xu, thank you. http://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/664796

Economic and financial expansion will lead to higher demand for commodities leading to increased cost for goods. Services will also be impacted through employment growth and higher wages. January will signal this growth lasting throughout the spring.
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/641672 But weighting average bin more heavily to compensate for Fed reserve prevention intervention :D
I read it wrong... Nov 2016-Nov 2017 for Core CPI was 1.7% (bureau of labour statistics).
Sweet spot before a bubble - low inflation, high employment etc.  Although I went all in at 1.8-2.0 acknowledge it will be very close.

Overall inflationary pressure seems to be growing around the world.  Also, price variability is related to uncertainty and Trump has a whole month to do something more consequential than a tweet to roil financial markets.

Changes don't typically shift a huge amount month to month. I'm thinking December will have seen a slight growth and good sales. Revising to show more of a split between the 1.6-8 and 1.8-2 levels. Will revise again around the 12th when hopefully the December 2017 CPI numbers are released.

the numer is always quite similar to december. the forecast is 1.8. the changes are 0-0.2 so i assume it will be within the range of 1.6-1.8 at the upper, but not above. https://m.investing.com/economic-calendar/core-cpi-736

Chart last 20 years:  https://www.bls.gov/charts/consumer-price-index/consumer-price-index-by-category-line-chart.htm It never seems to change more than 0.2 percentage points in a month. November 2017 is 1.7%. So January is going to be between 1.3% and 2.1%. December number should be released in a couple of weeks. That should narrow it down.
A slight increase from current rate due to added stimulus.
INFLATION WILL RISE AS THE US ECONOMY OVER HEATS DUE TO TRUMPS TAX CUTS.

The new tax plan will overstimulate employment and cause wage and price inflation to finally kick in.  The Trump team wants an overheated economy now because they believe the  benefits will last through 2020 and the negatives will not be seen until after the next presidential election.

I think 15 states haave higher Min. Wage laws kicking in and that in turn will be be passed along, Weak Dolar, and strength in manufacturing a indicate a return to near normal inflation and COLA, GDP #'s.
Gut, based on 12 month rise in household and busdiness budget adjustments
Private sector industry growth that are not federally inhibited will yield higher results.

November data was released on Dec. 13.
https://www.bls.gov/news.release/cpi.nr0.htm edit 2017-12-28: during the first 10 months of the 12 that count toward this question, the CPI has grown 1.363%, which implies the combined change in CPI for the last two months of the 12 must be at least {
0.194% growth to get to 1.6% or more,
0.392% growth to get to more than 1.8%,
0.628% growth to get to 2.0% or more, and
0.885% growth to get to more than 2.2%} There'll be one more workday in January and one fewer workday in December than the last time around. December tends to contribute less CPI increase than does January.

We're looking at 12 month so I'm considering two major data points: GDP and Inflation. I considered M2 but it's a fairly linear growth. I also looked at the components of CPI but it seems to be a lot more noise. Macro trends seems to be evident (apparel and auto are down - real estate and medical continue to be positive increases). There doesn't seem to be a seasonal trend so January isn't really a thing. We also seem to be sitting right at the cusp of 1.8. The GDP and Inflation doesn't seem to have any correlation with the CPI (positive or negative). My N of 1 is basically if I feel that things I buy are cheaper or more expensive. More expensive seems to be the case but that doesn't help with spitting between the over/under at 1.8.  It seems like the main driver is the perception of consumer confidence. That being said, I think retail is going to come up short over the holiday season. The question is how much does that affect January pricing of the basket of goods?  IDK. so 90% chance it falls into 1.6-2.0. That more weighted between the 1.6-1.8. potentially lower and potentially higher. I think the release of November numbers will warrant an update.

I'm probably weighting the last couple years too much. Anyone know whether a December Fed rate hike in past years was thought to affect the January number or whether not enough time elapses for that to matter (or rate hike is otherwise irrelevant)?  [I was eyeballing this list https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Federal_Open_Market_Committee_actions#Historical_actions & noting December rate actions last couple years]

wish I hadn't joined this question.
I previously misread the question; oops.

Results were significantly Auto-correlated (most recent predicts next).    Simply using the most recent as my base case with a slight upward adjustment for the auto-correlation of errors.   Mid-point: 1.82%
STdev: 0.2% Results are largely as shown. Word of Caution:  The BLS rounds rather than truncates when the publish numbers, so actual ranges should reflect this rather than using specific ranges.
https://www.bls.gov/news.release/pdf/cpi.pdf + glancing at Table A and analogues.
This is roughly where things stand now, with little apparent price pressure coming.  Tax cut could push things a bit.
